title: 108_hr196
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Slave Memorial Act". The Congress acknowledges the historical enslavement of Africans in the United States and the economic exploitation of slave labor. Africans were treated as property upon arrival and provided free labor for over 250 years, contributing to the nation's agricultural prosperity. Slavery in the United States caused African Americans to suffer enormous damages and losses, including the loss of human dignity, liberty, careers, income, and opportunity. It denied them the fruits of their labor and was an immoral deprivation of life, liberty, and pursuit of happiness. Despite the achievements of African Americans in overcoming slavery, the nation failed to grant all Americans equal rights. Many African American slaves fought in wars for national freedoms, knowing they would never enjoy those freedoms. African American art, history, and culture reflect experiences of slavery and freedom, with struggles for recognition and dignity. There is a need for institutions and monuments to promote understanding of African American heritage and enhance racial harmony. On June 19, 1865, the last group of slaves were informed of their freedom, marking the historic abolition of slavery. Congress should recognize this day, express regret to African Americans, and support reconciliation efforts. SEC. 3. NATIONAL SLAVE MEMORIAL. The National Foundation for African American Heritage is authorized to establish a memorial in Washington D.C. to acknowledge the injustice of slavery and honor those who contributed to the United States. The memorial will be located near the Lincoln Memorial. The National Foundation for African American Heritage is authorized to establish a memorial near the Lincoln Memorial in Washington D.C. The Secretary of the Interior and the National Capital Memorial Commission must recommend the location within 6 months. The Act complies with the Commemorative Works Act. The Foundation will solicit design proposals within 6 months and select a design within 2 years. The Secretary of the Interior, in coordination with the Smithsonian Institution, may accept donations to fund the design, construction, and maintenance of the memorial. Accepted funds will be deposited into a separate account in the Treasury for this purpose, available for expenditure without further appropriation. The Secretary of the Interior will provide periodic reports to Congress on activities related to the memorial every 6 months. A final report, including the recommended design, will be submitted within 2 years of the Act's enactment. Authorization of appropriations is also included in the Act. Authorization of appropriations is granted to the Secretary of the Interior for the memorial's construction, with a requirement that at least half of the total cost must come from private donations.
